topic_name: Strategies for Enhancement in Food Production

canonical_explanation.text:
Strategies for enhancement in food production encompass a range of biological techniques aimed at improving the quality and quantity of food from both plant and animal sources. Animal husbandry is the scientific management of animal livestock and includes dairy farm management, poultry farming, fisheries (aquaculture and pisciculture), apiculture (bee-keeping), and sericulture (silk production). Breeding strategies in animals include inbreeding (mating closely related animals to increase homozygosity), outbreeding (mating unrelated animals), cross-breeding (mating superior males of one breed with superior females of another), and interspecific hybridisation. MOET (Multiple Ovulation Embryo Transfer Technology) is used to improve the success rate of breeding programmes in cattle.

Plant breeding is the purposeful manipulation of plant species to create improved varieties. The main steps include germplasm collection, evaluation and selection of parents, cross-hybridisation, selection and testing of superior recombinants, and release of improved varieties. Several disease-resistant varieties have been developed such as Himgiri wheat (resistant to leaf rust, stripe rust, and hill bunt) and Pusa Swarnim mustard (resistant to white rust). Tissue culture involves growing plant cells or tissues in sterile nutrient medium to regenerate whole plants (somaclones). Somatic hybridisation involves fusion of protoplasts from different species to form hybrid plants. Single cell protein (SCP) from organisms like Spirulina addresses protein-rich food demands. Biofortification aims at breeding crops with higher nutrient levels, such as iron-fortified rice and vitamin A-rich golden rice, to combat malnutrition.
rules: Animal husbandry involves scientific management of livestock including cattle, poultry, fish, bees and silkworms
Inbreeding increases homozygosity and exposes harmful recessive alleles (inbreeding depression)
Outbreeding includes out-crossing (same breed, no common ancestors for 4-6 generations), cross-breeding, and interspecific hybridisation
MOET (Multiple Ovulation Embryo Transfer Technology) uses hormones to induce superovulation for rapid herd improvement
Plant breeding steps: germplasm collection → evaluation → hybridisation → selection of superior recombinants → testing and release
Disease-resistant varieties: Himgiri wheat (leaf rust, stripe rust, hill bunt), Pusa Swarnim mustard (white rust)
Tissue culture: growing plant cells on sterile nutrient medium; totipotency allows regeneration of whole plants
Somatic hybridisation: fusion of protoplasts of different species using PEG to form somatic hybrids
Single cell protein (SCP): protein-rich microbial biomass (e.g., Spirulina) grown on industrial waste as food supplement
Biofortification: breeding crops for higher vitamins, minerals, proteins and fats (e.g., iron-fortified rice, vitamin A-rich golden rice)
Aquaculture is rearing aquatic organisms; pisciculture specifically refers to fish farming
Apiculture (bee-keeping) uses Apis mellifera for honey production; sericulture uses Bombyx mori for silk

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the most common species of honeybee reared in India for commercial honey production?
questions.explanation_correct: Apis mellifera (Italian bee) is the most commonly reared species for commercial honey production due to its high honey yield, gentle nature, and ability to be maintained in artificial hives.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Apis dorsata is the rock bee (wild, not easily domesticated). Apis florea is the little bee (low honey yield). Apis cerana indica is the Indian bee, traditionally used but now largely replaced by Apis mellifera for commercial apiculture.

questions.question_text: Inbreeding in animal husbandry refers to:

options.text: Mating of unrelated animals of the same breed
Mating of animals belonging to different species
Mating of more closely related individuals within the same breed for 4-6 generations
Mating of superior males of one breed with superior females of another breed

questions.explanation_correct: Inbreeding involves mating closely related individuals within the same breed for 4-6 generations. It increases homozygosity and helps in developing pure lines but may lead to inbreeding depression if continued.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mating of unrelated animals of the same breed is out-crossing. Mating of different species is interspecific hybridisation. Mating superior males of one breed with females of another is cross-breeding. Inbreeding specifically involves closely related animals.

questions.question_text:
The

















term 'aquaculture' refers to:

options.text: Culture of aquatic organisms such as fish, prawn, and molluscs

questions.explanation_correct: Aquaculture refers to the culture and rearing of aquatic organisms including fish, prawns, crabs, and molluscs in controlled aquatic environments for food production.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rearing only freshwater fishes is too narrow a definition; aquaculture includes marine organisms too. Keeping honeybees is apiculture. Rearing silkworms is sericulture. Aquaculture is a broad term for all aquatic organism culture.

questions.question_text: Inbreeding depression in livestock is caused by:

options.text: Continuous inbreeding leading to reduced fertility and productivity

questions.explanation_correct: Inbreeding depression occurs when closely related animals are mated for several generations, leading to increased homozygosity of harmful recessive alleles. This causes reduced fertility, productivity, and overall fitness.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cross-breeding introduces genetic diversity and does not cause inbreeding depression. Interspecific hybridisation combines different species' genes. Out-crossing also introduces variation. Only continued inbreeding causes this problem.

questions.question_text: A cattle breeder wants to improve milk production in his herd quickly using hormonal treatment and embryo collection. Which technique should he use?
questions.explanation_correct: MOET involves administering hormones (FSH-like) to a cow to induce superovulation, producing 6-8 eggs per cycle instead of one. After fertilisation, the embryos are collected and transferred to surrogate mothers, enabling rapid herd improvement.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Artificial insemination improves breeding but does not multiply embryos. Natural mating is slow. Inbreeding increases homozygosity but may cause depression. MOET is the technique specifically designed for rapid multiplication of superior animals.

questions.question_text: Hisardale is a new breed of sheep developed in Punjab by crossing Bikaneri ewes with Marino rams. This breeding strategy is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: Cross-breeding involves mating superior males of one breed with superior females of another breed. Hisardale was developed by crossing Bikaneri ewes (Indian breed) with Marino rams (exotic breed), combining desirable traits of both.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Inbreeding involves mating closely related animals within the same breed. Out-crossing is mating within the same breed but with unrelated animals. Interspecific hybridisation involves mating different species. This is cross-breeding as two different breeds of the same species are crossed.

questions.question_text: A poultry farmer observes that his birds are showing reduced egg production and increased disease susceptibility after several generations of mating within a small flock. What is the most likely cause?
questions.explanation_correct: Inbreeding depression results from continuous mating within a small, closely related flock. It leads to increased homozygosity of deleterious recessive alleles, causing reduced fertility, egg production, and disease resistance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Nutritional deficiency would show specific symptoms, not generational decline. Outbreeding depression is very rare in domestic animals. Genetic drift affects small populations but the described pattern specifically indicates inbreeding depression.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a product of apiculture?
questions.explanation_correct: Silk is a product of sericulture (silkworm rearing using Bombyx mori), not apiculture. Apiculture is bee-keeping, and its products include honey, beeswax, royal jelly, propolis, and bee venom.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Honey is the primary product of apiculture. Beeswax is secreted by worker bees and used commercially. Royal jelly is a nutritious secretion used to feed queen larvae. These are all genuine products of apiculture; only silk comes from sericulture.

questions.question_text:
In MOET, the





















































cow is administered hormones with FSH-like activity. What is the primary purpose of this hormonal treatment?

options.text: To induce superovulation producing 6-8 eggs per cycle
To select the sex of the offspring

questions.explanation_correct: In MOET, hormones with FSH-like activity are administered to the cow to induce superovulation, causing the ovaries to release 6-8 eggs per oestrous cycle instead of the usual one. This allows multiple embryos to be produced from a single superior cow.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The hormonal treatment does not increase gestation period; it acts on the ovaries. It does not prevent fertilisation; rather, the cow is mated or artificially inseminated after superovulation. Sex selection is not the purpose of FSH-like hormones in MOET.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: Out-crossing is the best breeding method for animals that are below average in productivity.
Reason: Out-crossing involves mating of animals within the same breed but having no common ancestors on either side for 4-6 generations.

Select the correct option:

options.text: Both assertion and reason are true, and reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true, but reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion is true but reason is false
Assertion is false but reason is true

questions.explanation_correct: Both statements are correct. Out-crossing is the mating of animals within the same breed that have no common ancestors for 4-6 generations. It is the best strategy for animals below average in productivity as it introduces genetic diversity and helps overcome inbreeding depression, which is why it works.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The assertion is true as out-crossing is indeed recommended for below-average animals. The reason correctly defines out-crossing and explains why it works — the introduction of genetic variability from unrelated animals within the same breed restores vigour and productivity.

questions.question_text: A mule is produced by crossing a male donkey with a female horse. This is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: The mule is produced by interspecific hybridisation — crossing individuals of two different species (male donkey, Equus asinus, and female horse, Equus caballus). The offspring (mule) is usually sterile due to differences in chromosome number.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Out-crossing is within the same breed. Cross-breeding is between different breeds of the same species. Inbreeding is between closely related individuals of the same breed. Since donkey and horse are different species, this is interspecific hybridisation.

questions.question_text: Pisciculture specifically refers to:
questions.explanation_correct: Pisciculture refers specifically to the farming and rearing of fish under controlled conditions. It is a branch of aquaculture that focuses exclusively on fish production.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rearing of silkworms is sericulture. Rearing of honeybees is apiculture. Culture of all aquatic organisms is the broader term aquaculture. Pisciculture is specifically limited to fish farming.

questions.question_text:
In a dairy farm, the


 quality and quantity of milk production depends primarily on:

options.text: The breed of the cattle and adequate feeding
The size of the dairy farm building

questions.explanation_correct: Milk production in dairy farming depends on the selection of good breeds with high yielding potential and providing them with adequate, nutritious feed. Proper housing, hygiene, and health care of animals also play important roles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The number of farm workers and farm building size are logistical factors, not primary determinants of milk quality. Colour of cattle has no relation to milk production. Breed selection and nutrition are the most critical factors.

questions.question_text:
The





 first step in a plant breeding programme is:

options.text: Selection and testing of superior recombinants

questions.explanation_correct: The first step in any plant breeding programme is the collection of variability, also known as germplasm collection. This involves collecting and preserving all the diverse alleles for all genes in a given crop species along with its wild relatives.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Evaluation and selection of parents is the second step. Cross-hybridisation comes third. Selection and testing of superior recombinants follows hybridisation. Without a diverse germplasm collection, no effective breeding programme can be initiated.

questions.question_text: Himgiri, a variety of wheat, is resistant to:

options.text: Leaf rust, stripe rust, and hill bunt

questions.explanation_correct: Himgiri is a wheat variety developed through plant breeding that shows resistance to leaf rust, stripe rust, and hill bunt — three major fungal diseases of wheat in India.
questions.explanation_incorrect: White rust affects mustard, not wheat (Pusa Swarnim is resistant to it). Bacterial blight affects rice (not wheat). Late blight affects potato. Tobacco mosaic virus affects tobacco. Himgiri wheat is specifically resistant to rusts and bunt.

questions.question_text: Somaclones are obtained through:
questions.explanation_correct: Somaclones are genetically identical plants obtained through tissue culture of somatic cells. Small pieces of plant tissue (explant) are cultured on sterile nutrient medium containing growth regulators, and whole plants are regenerated from the callus.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cross-pollination produces genetically variable offspring, not clones. Grafting is a vegetative propagation method but does not produce somaclones. Hybridisation and selection produce new varieties but not somaclones. Tissue culture specifically produces somaclones.

questions.question_text: Which variety of Brassica (mustard) is resistant to white rust?
questions.explanation_correct: Pusa Swarnim is a variety of Brassica (mustard) that has been bred to be resistant to white rust, a fungal disease caused by Albugo candida that affects mustard crops.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pusa Komal is a cowpea variety resistant to bacterial blight. Pusa Sadabahar is a chilli variety resistant to chilli mosaic virus. Pusa Shubhra is a cauliflower variety resistant to black rot and curl blight. Pusa Swarnim is the correct mustard variety.

questions.question_text: In somatic hybridisation, protoplasts of two different plant species are fused using:
questions.explanation_correct: In somatic hybridisation, protoplasts (cells with cell walls removed by cellulase and pectinase) of two different species are fused using polyethylene glycol (PEG) or electric stimulation (electrofusion) to produce somatic hybrids.
questions.explanation_incorrect: DNA ligase joins DNA fragments, not cells. Restriction enzymes cut DNA at specific sequences. Taq polymerase is used in PCR for DNA amplification. PEG is the fusogen used to fuse protoplasts in somatic hybridisation.

questions.question_text: A plant breeder wishes to combine the disease resistance of one variety with the high yield of another variety. Which step in plant breeding directly achieves this?
questions.explanation_correct: Cross-hybridisation among selected parents is the step where desired traits from two different varieties are combined. The disease-resistant parent and high-yielding parent are crossed, and the resulting progeny may carry both traits.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Germplasm collection only gathers genetic material. Evaluation identifies desirable parents but does not combine traits. Release of the variety comes at the end. Cross-hybridisation is the key step for combining traits from different parents.

questions.question_text:
The




















ability of a single plant cell to develop into a complete plant is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Totipotency is the inherent capacity of a plant cell to give rise to a whole new plant. This property is exploited in tissue culture, where somatic cells are cultured on nutrient medium and regenerated into complete plants.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pluripotency refers to the ability to form many but not all cell types. Multipotency is the ability to form several related cell types. Unipotency is the capacity to form only one cell type. Totipotency is the complete developmental potential of plant cells.

questions.question_text:
In tissue culture, the










































































explant is first grown on a medium to form an undifferentiated mass of cells called:
questions.explanation_correct: In tissue culture, the explant (plant tissue) is placed on nutrient medium containing auxins and cytokinins. It first forms an undifferentiated mass of actively dividing cells called callus. The callus is then transferred to a differentiation medium to regenerate shoots and roots.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An embryo is an undeveloped plant from a zygote. A somatic hybrid results from protoplast fusion. A protoplast is a cell without a cell wall. Callus is specifically the undifferentiated mass formed during tissue culture.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly represents the sequence of steps in a plant breeding programme?

options.text: Hybridisation → Germplasm collection → Selection → Testing → Release
Germplasm collection → Evaluation and selection of parents → Hybridisation → Selection of superior recombinants → Testing and release
Evaluation → Hybridisation → Germplasm collection → Release → Testing
Selection → Hybridisation → Germplasm collection → Evaluation → Release

questions.explanation_correct: The correct sequence of plant breeding is: (1) Germplasm collection and preservation, (2) Evaluation and selection of parents, (3) Cross-hybridisation among selected parents, (4) Selection and testing of superior recombinants, and (5) Testing, release, and commercialisation of new cultivars.
questions.explanation_incorrect: All other options have the steps in incorrect order. Germplasm collection must come first as it provides the raw genetic material. Evaluation follows to identify desirable parents. Only then can hybridisation be performed meaningfully.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: Somatic hybridisation allows the combination of desirable traits from two different species that cannot be crossed sexually.
Reason: Protoplasts from two different species are fused to form a hybrid cell that can be grown into a new plant.

Select the correct option:

options.text: Both assertion and reason are true, and reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true, but reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion is true but reason is false
Assertion is false but reason is true

questions.explanation_correct: Both statements are correct. Somatic hybridisation overcomes sexual incompatibility barriers between species by fusing their protoplasts. The reason explains the mechanism (protoplast fusion) that makes the assertion possible — the hybrid cell contains the genome of both species and can be grown into a complete plant.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The assertion is correct as somatic hybridisation does combine traits of sexually incompatible species. The reason is also correct and directly explains how this is achieved — through protoplast fusion. Therefore both are true, and the reason correctly explains the assertion.

questions.question_text: Which of the following pairs of a crop variety and the disease it is resistant to is correctly matched?
questions.explanation_correct: Himgiri is a wheat variety resistant to leaf rust, stripe rust, and hill bunt. This is the correct match among the given options.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pusa Komal is a cowpea variety resistant to bacterial blight, not white rust. Pusa Sadabahar is a chilli variety resistant to chilli mosaic virus, not bacterial blight. Pusa A-4 is a flat bean variety resistant to Jassids, not leaf curl.

questions.question_text: In tissue culture, enzymes used to remove the cell wall of plant cells to obtain protoplasts are:
questions.explanation_correct: Cellulase and pectinase are used to digest the cell wall of plant cells to obtain protoplasts (naked cells). Cellulase degrades cellulose and pectinase degrades pectin, the two major components of the plant cell wall.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Amylase digests starch and lipase digests fats — neither affects cell walls. Protease and nuclease degrade proteins and nucleic acids respectively. Ligase joins DNA and helicase unwinds DNA. Only cellulase and pectinase target cell wall components.

questions.question_text:
The















































Green Revolution in India was primarily due to improved varieties of:
questions.explanation_correct: The Green Revolution in India (1960s-70s) was primarily driven by the introduction of high-yielding, semi-dwarf varieties of wheat (by Norman Borlaug) and rice (IR-8). These improved varieties, combined with better agricultural practices, dramatically increased food grain production.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pulses and oilseeds did not contribute significantly to the Green Revolution. Sugarcane and cotton are commercial crops, not the primary focus. Maize and millets improvements came later. Wheat and rice were the key crops of the Green Revolution.

questions.question_text: Semi-dwarf varieties of wheat were developed by:
questions.explanation_correct: Norman E. Borlaug, known as the father of the Green Revolution, developed semi-dwarf varieties of wheat (such as Sonalika and Kalyan Sona adapted for India) at CIMMYT, Mexico. These varieties had shorter stems that could support heavy grain loads without lodging.
questions.explanation_incorrect: M. S. Swaminathan adapted and introduced these varieties into India but did not originally develop them. William S. Gaud coined the term 'Green Revolution'. Gregor Mendel is the father of genetics, not plant breeding for the Green Revolution.

questions.question_text: Single cell protein (SCP) refers to:

options.text: Protein extracted from a single cell of an animal
Protein-rich biomass of microorganisms grown on industrial scale
A protein molecule with a single polypeptide chain
Protein produced by a single gene

questions.explanation_correct: Single cell protein (SCP) is the protein-rich biomass or dried cells of microorganisms like algae, bacteria, fungi, or yeasts that are grown on an industrial scale and used as food or animal feed to meet protein demands.
questions.explanation_incorrect: SCP is not protein from a single animal cell. It is not a single polypeptide chain — that describes a protein structure. It is not produced by a single gene. SCP refers to the entire microbial biomass rich in proteins grown for food purposes.

questions.question_text: Which microorganism is commonly used for single cell protein production?
questions.explanation_correct: Spirulina is a cyanobacterium (blue-green alga) widely used for single cell protein production. It grows rapidly, has high protein content (up to 60-70%), and can be grown on waste water from potato processing plants, making it an economical food source.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rhizobium is a nitrogen-fixing bacterium used as biofertiliser. Lactobacillus is used in curd and cheese preparation. Streptococcus is often pathogenic. Spirulina is the most commonly cited organism for SCP production in NCERT.

questions.question_text: Biofortification is a strategy aimed at:

options.text: Using chemical fertilisers to increase crop yield
Breeding crops with higher levels of vitamins, minerals, and proteins
Using pesticides to protect crops from diseases
Adding nutrients to processed food products

questions.explanation_correct: Biofortification is the breeding of crops with higher levels of vitamins, minerals, proteins, and healthier fats. It aims to improve the nutritional quality of food crops to combat widespread nutrient deficiencies, especially in developing countries.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Chemical fertilisers increase yield, not nutritional content. Pesticides protect against pests, not improve nutrition. Adding nutrients to processed food is food fortification (industrial), not biofortification. Biofortification is achieved through plant breeding.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of a biofortified crop?
questions.explanation_correct: Golden rice is a biofortified crop that has been engineered to contain beta-carotene (provitamin A) in the rice grain, which gives it a golden colour. It was developed to address vitamin A deficiency prevalent in populations dependent on rice.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bt cotton is a transgenic pest-resistant crop, not biofortified. Flavr Savr tomato was engineered for delayed ripening. Roundup Ready soybean is herbicide-tolerant. Golden rice is the classic example of biofortification with enhanced nutritional value.

questions.question_text: A scientist wants to address protein malnutrition in a developing country using microbial technology. Which approach would be most suitable?

options.text: Culturing Spirulina as single cell protein on industrial waste

questions.explanation_correct: Culturing Spirulina as SCP is ideal for addressing protein malnutrition. Spirulina has very high protein content (60-70%), can be grown on waste substrates cheaply, grows rapidly, and requires minimal resources, making it suitable for developing countries.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Antibiotic production addresses disease, not malnutrition. Rhizobium improves soil nitrogen for plants, not direct protein supply. Biogas production provides energy, not protein. SCP from Spirulina directly provides protein-rich food.

questions.question_text: Which of the following crops has been biofortified for increased iron and zinc content?
questions.explanation_correct: Atlas 66 is a wheat variety that has been used as a source of high protein content in biofortification programmes. Wheat varieties have been developed with higher iron and zinc content through breeding using Atlas 66 as a parent.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bt brinjal is a transgenic insect-resistant variety. Flavr Savr tomato has delayed ripening. Pusa Komal cowpea is a disease-resistant variety. Atlas 66 is specifically associated with biofortification for enhanced mineral and protein content.

questions.question_text: An advantage of using microorganisms as a source of single cell protein over conventional agriculture is:

options.text: Microorganisms require more land and resources
Microorganisms can be grown on industrial waste, reducing environmental pollution
SCP has lower protein content than conventional crops
Microorganisms grow slower than crop plants

questions.explanation_correct: A major advantage of SCP is that microorganisms can be grown on industrial effluents and agricultural waste as substrates. This not only reduces environmental pollution but also converts waste into nutritious food. Additionally, microorganisms have very fast growth rates.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Microorganisms require far less land and resources than conventional agriculture. SCP generally has higher protein content than most crops. Microorganisms grow much faster than crop plants due to short generation times.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a correct example of biofortification?
questions.explanation_correct: Adding iodine to common salt is food fortification (an industrial process of adding nutrients to processed food), not biofortification. Biofortification specifically involves breeding crop plants to enhance their nutritional quality through conventional breeding or genetic engineering.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Iron-fortified rice, vitamin A-enriched crops, and protein-enriched beans can all be achieved through biofortification (plant breeding). Adding iodine to salt is an industrial food fortification process, which is fundamentally different from biofortification.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: Spirulina can be grown on waste water and is used as food supplement.
Reason: Spirulina is rich in protein, minerals, fats, and vitamins.

Select the correct option:

options.text: Both assertion and reason are true, and reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true, but reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion is true but reason is false
Assertion is false but reason is true

questions.explanation_correct: Both statements are true. Spirulina can indeed be grown on waste water (such as from potato processing) and is used as a food supplement. Spirulina is also rich in protein, minerals, fats, and vitamins. However, the reason it can be grown on waste water is its ability to utilise waste substrates for growth, not because of its nutritional content. Hence the reason does not correctly explain the assertion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The assertion is true — Spirulina grows on waste water. The reason is also true — it is nutritionally rich. But the reason explains why Spirulina is a good food supplement, not why it can grow on waste water. These are two independent facts.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about biofortification is INCORRECT?

options.text: It involves breeding crops with higher nutritional quality
It can improve vitamin, mineral, and protein content of crops
It can only be achieved through genetic engineering, not conventional breeding
It is aimed at improving public health by combating nutrient deficiencies

questions.explanation_correct: The statement that biofortification can only be achieved through genetic engineering is incorrect. Biofortification can be achieved through both conventional plant breeding and genetic engineering (transgenic approaches). Many biofortified varieties have been developed using conventional breeding techniques.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Breeding crops with higher nutritional quality is the definition of biofortification. Improving vitamin, mineral, and protein content are valid objectives. Combating nutrient deficiencies is a key goal. The incorrect statement is that it requires genetic engineering only.

questions.question_text:
Match the following columns:

Column I: (a) Spirulina, (b) Atlas 66, (c) Golden rice, (d) Iron-fortified rice
Column II: (i) Vitamin A, (ii) SCP, (iii) High protein, (iv) Mineral enrichment
questions.explanation_correct: Spirulina is used for SCP (single cell protein) production (a-ii). Atlas 66 is a wheat variety with high protein content used in biofortification (b-iii). Golden rice is enriched with beta-carotene (provitamin A) (c-i). Iron-fortified rice has enhanced mineral (iron) content (d-iv).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Each item has a specific association based on NCERT content. Spirulina is the SCP organism. Atlas 66 is known for protein enrichment. Golden rice contains vitamin A precursor. Iron-fortified rice is about mineral enrichment.

questions.question_text: Mushrooms like Agaricus bisporus are cultivated as food because they are rich in:
questions.explanation_correct: Mushrooms such as Agaricus bisporus (button mushroom) are cultivated because they are an excellent source of proteins, minerals, and vitamins. They are low in calories and fat, making them a nutritious food source.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mushrooms are low in fats and carbohydrates. They are not rich only in vitamins; protein content is significant. They do not contain starch. Mushrooms are valued primarily for their protein and mineral content.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an advantage of artificial insemination in cattle breeding?

options.text: It eliminates the need for superior bulls
Semen from a superior bull can be used to inseminate many cows

questions.explanation_correct: Artificial insemination allows semen from a single superior bull to be collected, preserved, and used to inseminate a large number of cows across different locations. This maximises the genetic contribution of desirable males.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Superior bulls are still required as the source of semen. Artificial insemination does not determine the sex of offspring. It has no effect on gestation period. The key advantage is the widespread use of semen from genetically superior males.

questions.question_text:
In poultry farming, the
































term 'broiler' refers to:
questions.explanation_correct: In poultry farming, broilers are chickens specifically bred and raised for meat production. They are genetically selected for rapid growth and efficient feed conversion to produce maximum meat in a short period.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hens raised for egg production are called layers, not broilers. Male chickens for breeding are called roosters or cocks. Newly hatched chicks are simply called chicks. Broilers are specifically meat-type poultry birds.

questions.question_text: Mutation breeding has been used to develop which of the following improved crop varieties?

options.text: Mung bean resistant to yellow mosaic virus
Golden rice enriched with vitamin A
Flavr Savr tomato with delayed ripening

questions.explanation_correct: Mung bean varieties resistant to yellow mosaic virus and powdery mildew were developed through mutation breeding. In this approach, mutations are induced using mutagens, and the resulting variants with desired traits are selected and used in breeding programmes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bt cotton is a transgenic crop developed using genetic engineering with Bt genes. Golden rice was developed through genetic engineering with beta-carotene genes. Flavr Savr tomato was genetically engineered. Mung bean resistance was achieved through mutation breeding.

questions.question_text:
The








collection of all the different alleles for all genes in a given crop species is referred to as:
questions.explanation_correct: Germplasm refers to the entire collection of plants, seeds, tissues, or genetic material that contains all the different alleles for all genes in a given crop species and its related wild species. It is the raw material for any plant breeding programme.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gene pool is the total genetic diversity in a population. Gene bank is a facility where germplasm is stored. Seed bank stores seeds for conservation. Germplasm specifically refers to the collection of genetic variability available for breeding.

questions.question_text: Sericulture is the rearing of:
questions.explanation_correct: Sericulture is the commercial rearing of silkworms (Bombyx mori) for the production of silk. The silkworm larvae feed on mulberry leaves and spin cocoons of silk fibre that are processed to obtain raw silk.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rearing honeybees is apiculture. Rearing fish is pisciculture. Rearing lac insects is lac culture. Sericulture specifically involves silkworm rearing for silk production using Bombyx mori.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements best explains why SCP production is considered sustainable?

options.text: Microorganisms can utilise industrial waste as substrate, grow rapidly, and produce high protein biomass
SCP production requires large areas of agricultural land
SCP can only be produced from genetically modified organisms

questions.explanation_correct: SCP production is sustainable because microorganisms have very short generation times (can double in minutes to hours), can utilise industrial waste and sewage as growth substrates (reducing pollution), and produce protein-rich biomass with minimal land and water requirements.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Microorganisms have short, not long, generation times. SCP production requires very little land compared to conventional agriculture. SCP can be produced from naturally occurring organisms like Spirulina, not only GMOs.

questions.question_text: Biofortification of crops aims to improve all of the following EXCEPT:
questions.explanation_correct: Biofortification aims to improve the nutritional quality of crops, including protein content, vitamin content, mineral content, and oil quality. Pesticide resistance is not a goal of biofortification; it falls under pest management and plant protection breeding.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Protein, vitamin, and mineral content improvement are all objectives of biofortification. Pesticide resistance is a separate breeding objective related to crop protection, not nutritional enhancement.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly describes MOET?

options.text: A cow is given hormones to produce one egg, which is fertilised naturally
A cow is given FSH-like hormones to produce 6-8 eggs; fertilised eggs are collected and transferred to surrogate mothers
Sperms are collected from bulls and directly injected into the uterus of cows
Embryos are produced by in vitro fertilisation only

questions.explanation_correct: In MOET, a cow is administered hormones with FSH-like activity to induce superovulation, producing 6-8 eggs instead of the usual one. The cow is then either mated or artificially inseminated. The fertilised eggs (embryos) at 8-32 cell stage are collected non-surgically and transferred to surrogate mothers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: MOET induces multiple eggs, not just one. It is not simply artificial insemination. While IVF can be part of the process, MOET specifically involves in vivo fertilisation followed by embryo collection and transfer. Option B correctly describes all key steps.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a correct statement about tissue culture?

options.text: Only reproductive cells can be used to regenerate whole plants
Tissue culture can be used to produce virus-free plants from meristem culture
Tissue culture requires soil as the growth medium
Plants produced through tissue culture show high genetic variation

questions.explanation_correct: Meristem culture (apical and axillary meristems) can be used to produce virus-free plants because meristematic cells are generally free from viral infections. This is an important application of tissue culture in producing disease-free planting material.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Any living plant cell with a nucleus (somatic cells) can be used due to totipotency, not just reproductive cells. Tissue culture uses sterile nutrient medium (agar-based), not soil. Plants from tissue culture (somaclones) are genetically identical, not variable.

questions.question_text: Which of the following crops has been developed with increased vitamin A content through biofortification?
questions.explanation_correct: Golden rice has been developed with increased vitamin A (beta-carotene) content through biofortification. It was created to combat vitamin A deficiency, which affects millions of people in Asia who depend on rice as a staple food.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Atlas 66 wheat is associated with high protein content. Pusa Swarnim is a disease-resistant mustard variety. Saccharum officinarum is sugarcane. Golden rice is the specific example of vitamin A biofortification.

questions.question_text: A farmer has a variety of wheat that is high-yielding but susceptible to stripe rust. He wants to develop a variety that is both high-yielding and resistant. What should be the next step after selecting the two parent varieties?

options.text: Perform cross-hybridisation between the high-yielding and resistant parents

questions.explanation_correct: After selecting the two parents (one high-yielding and one disease-resistant), the next step in the plant breeding programme is cross-hybridisation. The two parents are crossed, and the progeny is screened for individuals that combine both desired traits — high yield and stripe rust resistance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Releasing parents directly would not combine the traits. Germplasm collection is the first step, already done. Somatic hybridisation is used for sexually incompatible species, which is unnecessary here as both are wheat varieties. Cross-hybridisation is the logical next step.
